reviews.review_title: TIW: Space Jam: A new legacy I guess
reviews.content: Hey I'm Shibby and today I watched space jam a new piece of garbageWhere honestly to start, the animation is very lazy and horrible, it doesn't match up in any lip-synch department and very often there's extra syllables added to words that are spoken by characters. This whole movie feels like an eyesore. All of the characters look absolutely terrible when CGI, But even the 2-D animation feels rather lackluster on its own. Almost every attempt of humor is just a reference and this whole movie feels like a really long commercial. Like honestly why do I need clockwork orange in a kids movie, like did the film makers even WATCH that movie??? The original space jam wasn't great sure, but it was obviously good enough to make a sequel. All of the acting is terrible, the story is incredibly bland and formulated. This movie just simply feels like it's capitalizing on previous existing properties and adds absolutely nothing to anything it's capitalizing on. The soundtrack is garbage, which is dreadfully sad because the original space jam had a genuinely awesome soundtrack, whereas not a single song in this entire movie is actually good enough to remember after the movies finished. The writing is abhorrent, you can very visibly see that in the trailer. Honestly there's simultaneously tons to talk about with this movie that just fails on every single regard and yet nothing is actually worth talking about. If you haven't seen this movie already, stay away from it Ike the plague it is a genuinely excruciating painful headache to watch. 1/10.

The original movie was a good movie as well, but people act like it was amazing and is an instant classic purely for the nostalgia factor. The Looney Toons carry this sequel, the comedy really comes from their dialogue and animations. Lebron and his fam do a decent job at conveying a great message to young fathers raising children in this generation, even though it may come off as cheesy to some. Overall, highlights include seeing the Looney Toons back on the big screen with some comedic moments, aka the Mad Max scene, and a good message at the end. Don't understand the hate behind including the other warner bro franchises.
Don't let the negative reviews stop you from watching it. Stop comparing the 1st space jam and judging lebrons acting. Great family movie.
It's an awful movie, but "Notorious P. I. G." sent me.

reviews.review_title: Amazing? No. A good time? Yes.
reviews.content: A lot of reviews seem to take issue with A New Legacy not being "like the original" (and perhaps LeBron James rightfully insulting a certain so-called "politician"). I may not be blinded by nostalgia but let's be real, Space Jam isn't, well, the classic everyone thinks it is. I'm a 90s kid and I didn't think much of it then either. Trailers for the sequel played in front of nearly everything I saw the past couple months, and I've just about had it. Until I actually saw it. By no means is this a masterpiece but it sure is a lot of fun.The script - by six credited writers (four of whom receive story credit) - isn't winning any awards anytime soon (except maybe a Razzie), but the hackneyed cliches and tropes can be easily overlooked by a quality performance by LeBron James, his acting chops previously seen in 2015's Trainwreck, and Don Cheadle, who clearly knows what he's working with and spares no time in hamming it up far past eleven. The only real nitpick I have cast-wise is Zendaya as Lola Bunny. Now I'm a "Zswagger", having enjoyed her past work (Euphoria, The Greatest Showman and the Marvel Cinematic Universe), but the in-jokes at the previous, albeit standalone, film would have fared more comfortably with Kath Soucie.James plays a fictionalized version of himself, father of three, his youngest son Dom is a tech prodigy who doesn't want to follow in Dad's footsteps. While at Warner Bros. Studios, Dom is lured into the "Serververse" by rogue artificial intelligence Al-G-Rhythm (get it?), who wagers LeBron to a basketball game wherein his and Dom's freedom depends on winning. Upon being thrown through virtual space to Tune World, LeBron, now in 2D animation (hopefully, we'll get more of that in the near future), meets Bugs Bunny and learns that the other Tunes have been exploring other realities, persuaded by Al-G.Up to this point, it was all merely self-aware. Here, it takes being a WB product and kicking it right in the "balls". The realities are other assorted Warner-owned properties, including but not limited to, DC Comics, Harry Potter, Animaniacs, Hanna-Barbera, The Wizard of Oz and a number of considerably more adult-oriented franchises, i.e. Game of Thrones, RoboCop, Mad Max, The Matrix, Austin Powers, and Rick and Morty. But the barrage of cameos doesn't stop there; a blink-and-you'll-miss-it shows Bugs transforming into Internet meme Big Chungus, and at the big game, Beetlejuice, The Mask, the Gremlins, Pennywise, the Droogs from the ultraviolent Kubrick thriller A Clockwork Orange and (this still baffles me) Sister Jeanne of Ken Russell's highly controversial (and WB's equivalent of how Disney feels about Song of the South) The Devils. Her appearance is far more frequent and leaves one to wonder if the studio plans to acknowledge the film in any capacity anytime soon.In the long run, Space Jam: A New Legacy, while not necessarily good, is regardless entertaining. It's like Ready Player One or any given MCU movie: don't expect anything substantial, just go with it and have fun pointing out the Easter eggs. 2.5/5.
An over-hyped, over sensationalized piece of garbage. I hope they make no money off this... an entire waste of every resource. More importantly, a waste of your time.

reviews.review_title: Ralph Breaks The Internet - Warner Brothers Style
reviews.content: Prior to watching the film, I saw so many critics claiming that the original version had a soul and this one couldn't hold a candle to it. I couldn't understand what made them say that since the original was also a cash grab, taking advantage of Michael Jordan's popularity, reviving the Looney Tunes, and maybe trying to create a show for those little alien creatures from "moron planet." After watching this new version, I can now see the heart and soul of the original one and how this one lacks it.The first Space Jam was by no means a cinematic masterpiece, but it had effort, it was fun. It didn't have to try so hard. The Looney Tunes didn't have to try so hard to appease to their modern audience, they were still as looney as they were in the 30s - 60s and it worked ! The story was sloppy but still fun cos it had a cast that made it so. Michael Jordan didn't deliver an Oscar worthy performance or even a good performance for that matter, but you could tell he was having fun. It just worked, it was a mess, but it worked. I loved this film as a kid and I still enjoy it as an adult even though now I can see it's flaws better. But even with its flaws, it's still miles and miles better than this new version.Warner Brothers took the Disney route and decided to make a film where they show off all their intellectual properties in ways that aren't necessary. If "Ralph Breaks The Internet" left a bad taste in your mouth, then I suggest you avoid this new Space Jam film. They decided to cram almost every notable character, film, show from their library into the film. I guess they felt The Looney Tunes, alone, weren't enough to entertain this new generation of kids or (the more probable version) it's a shameless long ad for whatever streaming service they may have planned for the future.They tried to create a touching father, son story for the film but there's nothing touching about it cos we spend only one scene establishing that Lebron has high expectations for his son and his son can't reach them cos he's his own person. The movie latches to that one scene to carry the rest of the poorly written story. The villain in this film is the algorithm of Warner Brother's library, played by Don Cheadle, who wants Lebron for reasons I still can't understand. He lures Lebron to the Warner Brothers studio, Lebron brings his son with him to the meeting, Lebron refuses whatever deal was offered to him and from there Don Cheadle decides to kidnap Lebron and his son to get his way. Listen this "Al. G. Rithim" character is just a poorly written excuse to enter the world of Warner Brothers where you will be hit with intellectual property after intellectual property of Warner Brothers - just like Ralph Breaks The Internet. When Lebron goes into Looney Tunes world, Bugs Bunny is the only Looney Tune there cos the other Looney Tunes decided to explore the other universes in the Warner Brothers library. Yet another written excuse to show off the characters and films that Warner Brothers owns. Actually the final basketball game is the ultimate show off of all their intellectual properties.Now for The Looney Tunes in this film. They lost their classic touch, that even Space Jam in the 90's let them keep. This version made them cringe worthy with lines like "Haters gonna hate," Porky Pig raps, and the rest hardly speak. A couple of lines here and there, Daffy (a normally funny Looney Tune) is not funny at all in this film, Zendaya (fantastic as she may be) is no Lola Rabbit. Her voice doesn't match Lola at all. The only Looney Tune that stayed faithful to the classic was Marvin Martian, a Looney Tune, that was noticeably missing in the original version - not sure why since he was so popular in the 90's. All in all they're very underwhelming and take a backseat for the other intellectual properties that Warner Brothers wants to show off. It is through them that Lebron realizes that perhaps he was being too hard on his son cos he keeps trying to prevent them from being looney, for basketball purposes. They just tried really hard to make the Looney Tunes interesting to their modern young audience, which is a big mistake in my opinion. My 8 year old cousin loves the classic Looney Tunes as they are, he even watches the old cartoons on HBO Max, he doesn't need them to try to act urban or c0oL for him to like them. Also they included the "big chungus" meme cos "see kids, we're in with the times, haha Warner Brothers is just like you haha"This review is really dragging on, but I can write you a book on how this film is terrible and could never come close to the original Space Jam (which isn't even that high of a standard !) I thought Michael Jordan would've made a cameo, but instead the little alien villains from the original did and Michael B. Jordan made a cameo cos "haha, heehee, they got the wrong Michael Jordan !" I now see what the critics meant when they say the original Space Jam had a heart and a soul, cos after watching this awful reboot, you'll realize it did. There was effort put into the original Space Jam and something fun and memorable was actually created, this new version is a shameless cash grab that doesn't bother to hide that this is what it's doing. They've decided to follow in Disney's "no longer hiding it" cash grab footsteps and it is unfortunate. I hope I didn't see The Iron Giant so many times cos those disconnected, money hungry producers plan on doing a reboot of that awesome movie. I'm not even going to go over Lebron's acting skills cos he's not an actor and neither was Michael Jordan. Don Cheadle didn't even bother with his character, while everyone else was trying really hard to be funny or even give the impression that they were making an effort, Sarah Silverman included.3 stars, I would ideally leave it at 1, but my 8 year old cousin enjoyed it and at the end of the day he's the one they made this atrocity for. Yet even he agreed, that the original is better. I don't recommend this film at all, just stream the original one.

This movie feel like it was written by 10 years old kidsI don't know why they even bother making it SMHSave ur money guys
Go buy some food or anything else it'll better than spending on this garbage.

There was absolutely no freaking point in making this film other than money and promotionDon't watch it unless you're 2.(Apparently, I can't create a review if it's "too short"... this movie doesn't need 150 characters for me to tell you how bad it is 😂)

The original Space Jam had mediocre acting but an above average plot. It was was one of the few times since Who framed roger rabbit that used integration of live action and cartoon. It became an instant classic and a colt 90's kid sensation.Lebron has always wanted to be like Mike or considered greater so this movie feels forced. The plot makes no sense, it's poorly written, and it's main objective is to advertise for WB and peddle products.If your a kid now you can probably push aside the agenda and enjoy the new graphics with looney tune characters. However, I believe this movie deserves the terrible ratings it has received.

I believe NO, it was horrible and basically praising the "KING" lebron james over and over and over and over ..... you get my point. J. was a master piece. What happened hollywood?

This is a multi-billion dollar film and it shows dont go in expecting Schindler's list a d just love looney tunes. Think 1996 not 2021 dweebs.

It doesn't matter how good or bad this movie was going to be. There are powers that be and a specific group of people who were going to give 1 stars and complete negative reviews simply because it's LeBron James. They despise him, his stance on racial injustice, his influence, his anti-Trump views, etc. I wouldn't be surprised if they actually didn't watch the movie. At one point, this same group was giving "Black Panther" 1 stars stating ambiguous reasons trying to hide the fact that they simply didn't like a black hero having so much influence. I'll give this movie a 6. It's not a 10, but definitely not a 1.

reviews.review_title: Fame and Money doesn't make a great film!
reviews.content: This film was a perfect example that Fame and Money doesn't make anyone an actor and a great film. Wasn't it obvious that Lebron's team is going to win the final match, I find it utter nonsense when you know the end is fixed with no suspense at all. Just a lame film to get more fans.

Let me preface this review by saying that as a kid I loved the original Space Jam with Michael Jordan. When I heard that a new one was coming I felt that it seemed unnecessary since the story after all these years didn't need a continuation. The movie's existence didn't bother me in the slightest, though. The movie itself however was hard to sit through.The acting by LeBron is horrendous. It's even worse than Jordan's back in the day and that was surprising because he was alright in the Amy Shumer movie. The number of times his delivery is wooden is astonishing. Then the kid playing his son. You cannot blame him too much because of his age but it was a chore to watch him play throughout the movie. Production value seems lacking as well. The 2D animation ist fluid and the CGI characters just look weird. Especially the Looney Tunes like Bugs Bunny.Now to the actually important part... The story itself. The idea of an emotional algorhythm is quite a stretch but OK. However, the characters are almost all insufferable. LeBron is an ignorant character which he is supposed to, but to an extent that a redemption arc cannot really safe him and even later in the movie he's a show off and full of himself which rubbed me the wrong way. For instance instead of being called LeBron he's being mostly referred to as the 'King' which takes out all the potential for some kind of realistic friendship with the Tunes. His son is an idiotic brat that is all about himself, as well. The algorhythm is admittedly the antagonist, but the only reason for him to be be like that is that his feelings - as a program - are hurt. The only really likable people are in fact the Tunes. Unfortunately apart from Bugs and Lola Bunny no-one gets to really shine except from one little scene for most of them during the game.On a positive note, the message the movie wants to convene is nice. You be you and don't let anyone force you to be someone you're not. I laughed twice during this movie which isn't much for a comedy but I thought I'd mention it anyway.Generally speaking, this movie is boring most of the time, annoying at others and simply put a lazy cash grab for the studio which it additionally uses to market everything else that's from Warner Bros. From Harry Potter through Game of Thrones to the Matrix, the Mask and many others you see them in the movie. Not because they serve a purpose, no. The only reason is to remind you that they created those things as well and you love them probably.Avoid this movie would be my suggestion because it represents many things that are wrong with movies and media in our time.

Good gravy - I can't believe people are giving this movie such a hard time! Did you actually see the first one?! It's great fun - some great lines, awesome references and my 9 year old loved it. LIGHTEN UP.

This is simply a way for Lebron to make millions to spew hate back at people for the elite. Simple as that. The people who financed this farce should be fired. No one that watches basketball likes this man. His acting skills are nowhere to be found. Anyone with more than two brain cells knows this was a way to pay him to keep on talking garbage about America and true Americans.
I liked it not as good as the original but still had its moments, I was a bit disappointed when they introduced Jordan and is was the B version not the Original.
No one is expecting lebron to get an Oscar nomination so calm down. The CGI is awesome and it's fking funny.
One Word: narcissism.It's not a movie it's a hagiography. One big advertisment. A movie it is not. LeBron James cannot act and is simply not a very relatable and likable person.

reviews.review_title: Stop acting like the first one was masterpiece theatre
reviews.content: These super low reviews are just haters. Look, he ain't my favorite player either...but as a 90s kid I like this one so much better. Kids will love this for sure! It's definitely a new legacy.I love the casted versions of his real family. I also loved all of the nostalgia throwbacks and a few hilarious surprises that kids and adults will eat up for sure.The beginning was dry.. But once they actually get to the game...recruiting and playing...it got better. I didn't expect to literally lol. I was prepared to hate it. But I didn't. Solid watch - 6. Your kids will love it.

I saw "Space Jam:A New Legacy", starring LeBron James-Trainwreck, Entourage_tv; Don Cheadle-the Avengers movies, House of Lies_tv; Cedric Joe-Loving Him, Modern Family_tv and Sonequa Martin_Green-Star Trek:Discovery_tv, The Walking Dead_tv.This is a sequel to the original 1996 sports/cartoon collaboration-this one takes place in cyber space instead of outer space-and it still features a combination of live action and animation. LeBron is the sports figure here-Michael Jordan was in the original-that gets roped into the cyber world of an artificial intelligence bad guy played by Don. Cedric plays LeBron's son, who gets kidnapped by Don to force LeBron to play a game of basketball in the serververse-kind of like in the Matrix. LeBron's wife is played by Sonequa. LeBron enlists the Looney Toons characters-Bugs Bunny, Daffy Duck, etc,-to help him win and try to rescue his son. The effects are good and there are lots of cameos-mostly in the crowd scenes-to keep an eye out for, both real and animated. The cameos range from sports figures to Warner Bros. Properties and even other sources. I remember seeing King Kong, Batman & Robin, It, Game of Throne characters, Harry Potter characters, The Wizard of Oz characters....well, you get the drift. During the end credits, there are photos of the toons and real people-such as Porky Pig fighting Ronda Rousey-but nothing at the very end, except the signature line is heard, 'That's All, Folks!'.It's rated "PG" for cartoon violence and language and has a running time of 1 hour & 55 minutes.If you have little ones, it would be a good one for the family. I don't think I would buy it on DVD but it would be alright, as a rental.

reviews.review_title: Fails where the original Space Jam succeeded--being a watchable movie
reviews.content: The original Space Jam, if we remember, was this super exciting movie where we got to see the Looney Tunes intellectual property outside of their domain and interacting with the real world and THE Michael Jordan. Real celebrities and sports stars played themselves in the movie. It was meta, self-referential, and irreverent towards pop culture at the time. These concepts were really exciting in the 1990s-look at what Scream did with horror cliches, and what Casper did with celebrity cameos around the same time period. We loved it, and Space Jam capitalized on all of this stuff while still giving us a fun, watchable movie. The unfortunately can't be said for this new Space Jam.The original Space Jam managed to fit a pretty lean, economical screenplay around these pop culture references and goofy distractions--there's a very, very clear three-act structure with some A, B, and C storylines running throughout that generally all carry through pretty clear arcs and wrap themselves up sufficiently without much head-scratching afterwards. You can go back and watch the original and see that it is well-paced, there's nothing that feels unnecessary that makes the story drag or raise a bunch of questions, and it does a satisfactory job of just being a fun movie. It's an extremely easy watch. It's not a "good" movie, but it's a well executed family fun movie that hits all of its beats and gets out without overstaying its welcome. The acting is lousy and it feels like a cheesy 90s time capsule, because of course it is. But it is entertaining. It does its main job of just being a watchable movie.Going into the new Space Jam, I expected nothing except a watchable movie and getting to see Lebron goof around with the Looney Tunes, as well as the occasional pop culture gags/distractions.What I got, however, was a really, really tough watch.Lebron is written as a mean, domineering, out of touch father and his very first introduction onscreen is extremely unflattering as a result, which makes our protagonist highly unlikable from the very start.MJ in the original Space Jam was written as not only a loving father, but they managed to also successfully portray the greatest athlete of all time as an underdog, and we totally buy it. They even leveraged the actual events of his real life into the story to ground him and make him likable, and it paid dividends in the final product. It was a very, very shrewd way of using a meta approach to effectively drive storytelling forward. In this case, Lebron is kinda rude and makes his own kid resent him as a result. There is no attempt made at grounding Lebron's character in any way like MJ was. Lebron doesn't need to be an underdog per se, but give us something about him as a real person to root for at least. We got nothing from this screenplay in this regard.A little later on, the main conflict arises and I watch Lebron get sucked into the serververse by Don Cheadle to go on a frantic search for his kid. I'm basically going "wait, why is he suddenly so emotionally invested in this? He has been nothing but cold, mean, and distant with this kid the entire time." There was nothing particularly meaningful developed between Lebron and his son before the kid goes missing, so it's tough to buy that Lebron is just devastated that the kid is gone. On top of this, a completely unnecessary and extremely poorly fleshed out wrinkle is added as a way to raise the stakes--he has to find the son or else his millions of instagram followers get stuck in the server forever. The social media followers were and are never a part of the story and are simply thrown in to raise the stakes because the kid being gone clearly wasn't enough to get an audience invested (this is being used as a crutch for poor character development). It's a tough narrative sell and I don't buy it.In Space Jam 1, the motivations were incredibly simple yet effective: Michael has to get back in time for his baseball game. His family, who he deeply loves, will worry about him. The NBA players will lose their talent if he doesn't. They will all be slaves on Moron Mountain. All of these things are sufficiently developed and explained beforehand, so when they are used as leverage to raise the stakes for MJ, we totally buy it and are invested. These stakes feel real and scary, and we root so hard for the Tune Squad as a result. This new Space Jam story makes the old Space Jam screenplay feel like an economical masterpiece on par with Die Hard.I don't worry about the son's plight in this new Space Jam, because every interaction with the most important adult in his life (the movie's protagonist Lebron) that he's had up to this point has been extremely negative and the villain is the only adult in the movie who overtly connects with him on a personal level and encourages him in his pursuits. Being stuck in the server forever with a very supportive Don Cheadle and his cute lovable Pixar-style sidekick looks and feels like a far better option here--it doesn't feel like he's been kidnapped or is being held against his will whatsoever. The son is very, very clearly enjoying his time in captivity and it just kills the sort of damsel in distress archetype it's shooting for here. It's really, really bizarre to see a kidnapped kid enjoying his time and never, ever once asking, "where is my dad?" or maybe saying, "let me out of here, I want to go home." What is going on here?The movie is absolutely loaded with forced, hamfisted, and genuinely corny (not in a funny dad joke way) references to existing Warner Brothers IP. I believe I counted four (4) overt references to The Matrix of all things (remember in the late 90s when it was common to see a Matrix slo-mo bullet dodge reference? It obviously got old quickly, even back then). These all honestly get very old, very fast. There's too much, none of the references are creative or particularly funny, and they really do make the movie drag along more than it already is. It all just serves as filler. The same goes for the insane amount of CGI effects in this movie. I marveled at it, not only for how much work went into it by the artists, but also at how utterly unnecessary it was and how much it dragged out scenes to be way longer than they needed to be so that we could wait on actors to wave their hands and arms all over the place to interact with the CG stuff. If there's any way a CGI thing can be used, it is. There's zero discretion in this regard. It's pure filler and incredibly distracting most of the time. With all due respect to the artists and the hours they put in, its a huge technological achievement but incredibly over the top as a result. You really get the sense that this is what the movie is built around, rather than all of it being built around a movie.The original Space Jam has occasional cameos and some breaking of the fourth wall, and uses the Looney Tunes IP and some minor corporate product placement as part of the meta/self referential pop culture shtick it was doing. Some of these ideas and sequences have aged better than others, sure, but none of it feels unnecessarily forced or crazy over the top and it all went over fairly well originally without detracting from the story or taking time away from developing characters. They were built around the movie--the movie was not built around it.TL;DR: Ultimately, the new space jam fails where the original Space Jam succeeded--in being a watchable movie.
This movie really sucks.The michael cameo was super lame.The movie was just awful.Don't watch 1/100.

reviews.review_title: People who complain about this film forget the first Space Jam wasn't good either.
reviews.content: Space Jam: A New Legacy (2021) is a movie we recently saw in theatres two days ago. The storyline follows LeBron James who wants his son to be a basketball player while his son is more interested in designing and building video games. When WB approaches LeBron about a new campaign, which was designed by their own Artificial Intelligence (AI), LeBron hates the idea and turns it down, upsetting the AI. The AI decides to kidnap his son and only allows him to return home if Bron can beat the AI at a game of basketball. Bron will be given his team of toons to work with while the AI forms his own goon squad. This movie is directed by Malcolm D. Lee (The Best Man) and stars LeBron James, Don Cheadle (Crash), Sarah Silverman (School of Rock), Steven Yeun (Walking Dead) and Lil Rel Howery (Get Out). The storyline for the holistic movie is nothing special, but the toon characters are awesome and their introductions into the film was magnificent (the best segments of either film are in this picture - the Matrix and Mad Max sequences are legendary). I loved the background characters at the game and loved how Disney showed they do more than cartoons and super heroes (The Nun, It, Gremlins, etc). The animation for this film was excellent and superior to the first film (as you'd expect). Overall, this was a lot of fun for the family and a hair below the original. People who complain about this film forget the first Space Jam wasn't good either. I'd score this a 5/10 and recommend taking your kids to see it.

Initially I had no plans to watch this being a fan of the original, but given it was free on HBO Max as a family we decided to give it a go.Overall I'd say it wasn't completely terrible, but definitely wasn't as good as the first one. The story while good enough as a sequel was really brought down by the James family acting moments. LeBron and the kids were wholly unbelievable, but the mother was decent as the no nonsense member of their family.While the upgraded graphics were really good, the best parts of the movie were where they were cutting on LeBron for various things he has done in his career and Porky Pigs rap solo in my opinion.The only thing that may have saved this movie was if Michael Jordan really had walked into the locker room instead of Michael B. Jordan.This just seems to be another case of LeBron trying to prove he is better than Jordan.

reviews.review_title: One long marketing vehicle for Warner Bros
reviews.content: This film lacks the heart and whimsy that made the original so loved. It's simply a way for Warner Brothers to "flex" and constantly flash the names and logos of all the intellectual properties they own. Abundant special effects don't make up for the lack of a strong plot. And the ending is heartbreaking and pointless.

reviews.review_title: Is it Product Placement or Nostalgia?
reviews.content: I decided to watch the original Space Jam before watching this new one. I have to say I found it to be clunky and boring at times. Let's just say it hasn't aged well. Viewing it left such a bad impression that I waited a few weeks before watching the sequel.My expectations for the movie were low, given the many horrible reviews. After a slow start, the film took off and found its groove. I found myself laughing out loud several times. When done, I went and read the reviews. I don't get why there is so much hate. Nor why there is so much love for the original. Two key points I'd like to make.1) Many complained "this is just product placement" given the wealth of Warner television and movies scattered throughout the story. I have to wonder if these are the same people that were in awe of the same level of product in "Ready Player One." I guess that movie tugged at "nostalgia," but this one is only "product placement." Whatever. I didn't see it that way at all. Warner crammed this movie with so many Easter Eggs it will take multiple viewings and endless pause/rewind to find them. Just check out the endless YouTube videos out there listing what others have found. Personally, I absolutely LOVED this aspect of the movie.2) The original Looney Tunes cartoons often operated on two levels. Kids got the slapstick fun and silly gags. Adults often caught a different set of jokes targeted at them. So, when people complain about "Why are there these adult movie references in a kids movie?" The answer is simple - the joke is for the parents.I rated this movie an 8/10 because I think kids will have a blast. There's a heartwarming story woven throughout the film. The VFX are fantastic. I also feel the Warner references show a huge level of care and detail put into the script. Lebron does a fine acting job. IMO it runs about 15 minutes too long and could have used a bit more editing to improve the pace. Otherwise, it's a blast.

reviews.review_title: Could have been good I suppose
reviews.content: LeBron's acting sucked a lot out of this movie. He's the anchor and hero of the film and he wasn't fun to watch which made the movie a chore. He's not an actor, but at least he could have used charisma and personality to make up for it which he didn't. All the humans are unlikeable, which is unfortunate considering most of them are playing themselves. The best acting came from the cartoon characters lol. The only good thing were the special effects and I kinda liked the IP use when it came to Warner Bros using different worlds from their movies and shows but it got old fast and most of the time it was just blatant product placement and didn't really further the adventure in a fun and captivating way. The movie was also too long. I watched maybe the first 45 minutes and that was enough for me. It has WB corporate's slimy hands all over it. Zero replay value. Glad it bombed.

I really tried to enjoy it while watching it. But I just couldn't. I found myself checking to see how much time is left at least 5 different times and at one point I paused it to be on my phone for 30 mins. I never really laughed, the most this movie got out of me was a couple smiles. And that's it. Only time I came close to laughing was the Michael B Jordan. Cameo. That was pretty good. Other than that, I watched it and was disappointed and will never watch it again. I thought Lebron acted well for not having a lot of movies under his belt and he was funny in Trainwreck so I gave him the benefit of the doubt with this movie. Not even gonna compare it to the original. Doesn't compete. Even if the original didn't exist and this movie came out on its own it'd still be crap.

"Space Jam: A New Legacy" is an Animation - Comedy movie in which we watch a new version of "Space Jam" of 1996. Instead of Michael Jordan there is LeBron James who has to work together with Bugs Bunny and the Looney Tunes to win a basketball match and not letting artificial intelligence achieve its goal.Since I had already watched the first movie of "Space Jam" I knew what to expect from this new version of it. The direction which was made by Malcolm D. Lee was average without achieving to intrigued audience and make them feel that they are also a part of this movie following his main characters. The interpretations of LeBron James who played as himself, Don Cheadle who played as Al G. Rhythm and Cedric Joe who played as Dom James were good and their combination worked pretty good. To sum up, I have to say that "Space Jam: A New Legacy" is an average comedy movie and I advise you to lower your standards if you want to watch it otherwise you will be disappointed.

reviews.review_title: As a 90's Kid, I Thoroughly Enjoyed This Movie!!!
reviews.content: I was 6 years old when the original Space Jam came out. It's always been one of my childhood favorites. I never imagined that after 25 years, they'd actually make a sequel to it, and now that it's here; it really isn't all that bad. No way will it ever be as nostalgic as the original, but if you're a fan of the original, and love cinema, especially films and television shows made by Warner Bros. Then you're in for quite a surprise. There are many nods, pop culture references and Easter eggs to great franchises such as Harry Potter, Game of Thrones, Mad Max, The Matrix, Casablanca, The Wizard of Oz, King Kong, The Iron Giant, Rick and Morty, the DC Universe and much more.LeBron James stars as a fictionalized version of himself. (I feel weird for saying this, but LeBron showed more emotion than Michael Jordan did in the original. MJ seemed wooden and had hardly any emotion when he met the Looney Tunes. LeBron was legit excited to meet Bugs Bunny and treated him like a buddy.) At a young age, LeBron was taught that basketball is all work and no play.Fast forward to present day, he wants his children to follow in his footsteps, but his son, Dominic "Dom" wants to create video games. One day, LeBron and his family are invited to the Warner Bros. To discuss a movie deal, but when he and his son get into an argument, an evil computer A. I. named Al-G Rhythm abducts them and forces LeBron to play a high stakes basketball game against video game characters that his son created. Al-G gives LeBron 24 hours to put together a team, so he's sent to Looney Tune World and teams up with Bugs Bunny to put together the ultimate team. LeBron wants big powerful characters like Superman, King Kong and the Iron Giant, but Bugs just wants to get his ol' tune pals back together.This becomes one of the best scenes in the movie. LeBron, and Bugs visit other Warner Bros. Produced films to find all the remaining Looney Tunes. I won't spoil all the surprises. If LeBron and his team loses, then Al-G will take his son prisoner and abduct anyone who is livestreaming it on their cell phone. Welcome to the jam!If you grew up with the original, I implore you to give this new one a try. I was skeptical for awhile, but when I finally saw it, I really enjoyed it and I felt like a kid again. I highly recommend SPACE JAM: A NEW LEGACY!!!

Now i look around at these negative reviews: uninspired, apocalyptical disaster and overall bad reception.But in my opinion Space Jam: A New Legacy is a really good Movie!I thought the writing was good, although it felt really rushed, The different animation styles including the CGI looked amazing and the references just kept on coming. (SPOILER ALERT)From Pennywise to Rick and Morty to Batman to The Matrix, it was all very well done.The only problem I have is the corporate work here. The movie clearly doesn't seem to put much love into it and could feel a bit soulless sometimes. But as a critic, I'm supposed to look past my personal views and rate the movie the way its meant to be rated.Good movie, would recommend.

The movie is not terrible. I was a little lost on the story line and felt that the Al G Rythmn guy was sort of random (but given the son and what his passion was... I guess it makes sense). I legit was bummed when MJ was actually not in the movie... but overall it is family friendly and humorous in areas... it is good for the family! But keep in mind everyone is going to have an opinion about everything! I'd probably watch it again BUT not one of those movies where I could watch it over and over.

reviews.review_title: I don't understand these bad reviews!
reviews.content: Real rating - 7, trying to counteract all these negative reviews.This was a fun movie for me and the kids. I loved all the references to other movies and the cameos. It's definitely geared towards this generation of children with the video game/technology aspect.Give it a chance, don't listen to these negative reviews!

The movie provides 2h of original content for Shaqtin' a Fool.Every 5s scene where a real person appears on screen trying to act, would be a strong #1 Shaqtin' a Fool contender. The inside guys would have lots of fun with it.

Come on, it was funny. It just was. There were some unexpectedly great gags, fun references, and it was a good time. Is it the original? Of course not. Michael Jordan was a god to all children of the 90s and Lebron James is a likable athletic icon for today's kids. This one's for them, let them have it. It's not groundbreaking, but not every movie needs to be. It was a good time.

reviews.review_title: Great big CGI fart fest, filled with product placement.
reviews.content: This movie just wants you get excited cause you saw something you recognize. Big shock, LeBron isn't a very good actor and they barely even show him doing the thing he is good at, basketball. During the game he just leaping through the air in a CGI diaster. This movie desperately wants to connect with kids and is more concerned with references and video games than funny Looney tunes antics. Just watch something else, this sucks.

reviews.review_title: Starts slow... but becomes a really fun ride
reviews.content: The best thing about this is that it doesn't take itself too seriously. It's a ridiculous premise and yes, one giant Warner Bros promotion for all of its own properties. But none of that bothered me... because it's in on the joke, winking at us the whole time.The only real problem I had was there was way too much exposition at the beginning to setup what is a ridiculous and implausible premise that was going to be LOONEY to begin with. We could've had the same story beats at a snappier clip.Once we get into Tune World/The Serververse... this thing is a blast!Also, Lebron's acting improves greatly when it's for the sake of comedy. He's got great comedic timing... but he is NOT a dramatic actor. They spent way too long on the buildup... and I'm sure that's why a lot of reviewers have been down on this.But once the real fun begins, it's a truly great ride, especially for the little ones and the NBA fans.

Can we go back and not make this film it's atrocious.

As a 90s baby who grew up watching the original Space Jam, I'll admit that even that movie is really flawed, but this... this wasn't it. While I did enjoy some of the father/son moments, I think the first movie benefited from really just embracing the silliness from top to bottom. The plot was thin, but it was a Looney Tunes/NBA crossover; you don't really need to explain why everything's happening, just have fun getting there.This was fun at times, but it mainly felt like it was trying too hard to not be the first film (despite the in-film allusions to it), and got too bogged down by the need to remind you that LeBron was being a bad dad.
The film was strictly for children if u have a brain this isn't for you. The animations and visuals are great but everything is else is bad. Better to skip this than watch it.

Looney toons still shine and take center stage and Lebron is definitely a better actor than Jordan. Cameos are fun and there is a pretty close ratio of cartoon to cgi. Good fun summer movie. Yes there is cheese but what you would expect. Real rating- 6 or 7.

reviews.review_title: It's solid, but it's just not my Space Jam
reviews.content: I grew up on the original Space Jam movie and I loved it for the pure enjoyment of Bugs Bunny and the Looney Tunes. Is the original really that good to begin with?? Well, no. The original suffers from many of the same flaws that A New Legacy has, but ANL has just a few more. Michael Jordan in the original movie had some pretty stiff acting and Lebron James is the same way as well, except MJ's characterization felt a little more realistic while Lebron's was more over the top and lacked the soul that this film needed. Lebron and his "son's" story just didn't really mesh super well and made the film feel a bit off balance. Bugs and the gang were just as entertaining as ever though and Don Cheadle as the villain Al G Rithm was pretty amazing. The overall story itself was a lot more complex then it really needed to be which made it feel unnecessarily over the top constantly. I understand the premise of the franchise in general is insane, but at least the film from 96 managed to stay more grounded and balanced with its characters and story. Is A New Legacy really that bad? No, but the flaws are there and fairly noticeable, especially when you finish the film and it feels like you just missed something. It was still a fun enjoyable time and the concept is just fun for kids. A solid 6.5/10 for sure, but I'd watch again so maybe a light 7/10 on a good day.
Its like watching a Parody version of classic Space Jam 1996. Though only thing worth watching is WB character references & cameos.

reviews.review_title: Cleaning up warm cat vomit a more pleasant experience
reviews.content: Too bad the rating system doesn't include negative stars because that's what this movie deserves.
Cant say enough things about how awful this movie really is.

reviews.review_title: Who gave the green light for this trash?
reviews.content: LeBron chasing Jordan's legacy is as legitimate as this movie. Utter trash. No one will ever match what Jordan did in basketball but this movie just put the final nail in the coffin of GOAT. LeBron proves once again that the on,y consistency he offers is letting people down. Questionable NBA legacy and abominable movie career. Don't bother with this one.

Don't waste your time, Lebron James, Can't act, re-watch the first one as it has a lot more feeling attaching to it than this remake which is almost identical to the first one. As far as CGI and animation goes it has nothing on the first one.👎👎

Just saw it in theaters for my anniversary and loved it so much! It doesnt have the same feeling as the first one, but it settles into its own quite well. I was so worried about it trying to hard to be the OG space jam, but they really don't strive for that at all. It's all the warm fuzzy nostalgia mixed with modern day pop culture.As an individual whom uses social media as a huge part of my career I can confirm the algorithm really be acting like that. The villian though isn't really the main conflict though, and he plays a much smaller role than most villans so he's not super fleshed out. It works for this movie. I also loved seeing the traditional cartoon style with live action again, who framed Roger rabbit was a favorite in my childhood, the live action toons were a little off putting at first. Over all great movie, would definitely recommend.

reviews.review_title: Wile E Coyote in Mad Max Fury Road

This movie was beyond stupid in every way. What a shame.

BAGE. {Well it's saying my review is apparently too short but i think my review sums it up perfectly}

Got to laugh at all the bad reviews from people who liked the original "Space Jam" as a child, now dissing this remake as a grown adult, even though it was made for kids. This was good fun, don't let anyone tell you otherwise.A modern day remake, with one of today's most well known athletes, and all the classic Toon characters. I actively enjoyed myself for the entirety of the film.

reviews.review_title: Didn't expect much but this was painful to watch
reviews.content: The first Space Jam was cool when it came out because I was 9. It's silly today and I don't consider it a "great film." That said, I would actually watch it if I found it while flipping through channels.Space Jam: A New Legacy is a two hour tooth grinding headache. I only laughed at its audacity. It's a copout to say that the film is just supposed to be fun since that's a theme. It doesn't care about its audience. Watch it and find where the 150 million went into making this.

reviews.review_title: For Our Kids, Not For Us
reviews.content: The bad reviews are from adults expecting a follow up to the original Space Jam. This movie is for kids, not for adults. We already had our Space Jam, this is theirs and my son absolutely loved it.

reviews.review_title: LeBron should stick to ruining basketball

reviews.review_title: Colorful, fun, and a bit hallow as a movie.
reviews.content: 3 out of 5 stars.I loved the first Space Jam film which took Michael Jordan into a looney toon world to play ball. This film modernizes with the digital world of warner bros studios. Taking Lebron James into the digital world. Where he meets looney toons. And in order to get his son back. Which they had a conflict which Lebron always wanted his son to play ball but he is obsessed with making video games. Lebron James would have to form a team to play ball against a digitalized characters that would break the rules against basketball.Decent story about father and son. And a theme about doing what makes you happy. Lebron James is a fun addition. The visual effects and animations is great. Especially when it digitizes the toon characters. It is colorful. Fun. And it has a lot of cameos of warner bros characters.Acting was okay. Don Cheadle playing a villain was eh. The direction does get forgettable. And feels hallow when it comes to anything else. Like it feels like a one time view kind of movie. Until your bored with the humor.
Highlight was rick and morty.Lebron needs to stick to flopping on courts, his acting is horrendous.Save your money...

That's how you'll feel the whole movie, there's nothing on the line.Everything happens with ease, no real problems faced. Everything feels superficial, just happening because some lazy writer wrote so, all for conveinience to take your hard-earned cash with the last amount of effort.Even a 6 year old would write a better more indept movie. Now the Space Jam wasn't everything, but it at least felt like it had a soul. This "New Legacy" however is just a bunch of checkmarks on a generic plotline.If you don't watch it you don't miss anything, in fact you save yourself quite some time and most of all frustration and disappointment.

For all the characters and budget of this film is was a real let down to see this film turn out so poor.It is very obvious from the start and just seems like an advertising vehicle for the Warner brothers back catalogue.

SJ2ANL is fun and very well done! Pay no mind to the close-minded, low forheads, because "Haters hate"! The movie has substance and delivers a consistent theme throughout, which is heartfelt, universal, and clear to those who get it, who know, and resonates on many levels to many generations. The "Serververse" and the WB Universe rocks! The soundtrack is inspiring and up-to-date, and augments the FAMILY FUN, as does the cast that does a truly wonderful job in this standalone film. reviews.review_title: All you see is haters here my friend.

Stop comparing it to the first as well because it is not. It's not a 10 but I'm going to give it one anyways to help balance out these haters.

reviews.review_title: Pleasantly Surprised by this Awesome Sequel to the 90's Favourite.
reviews.content: Yes i grew up watching the original 90's Space Jam on video like most & have Nostalgic love for that movie but I'm so happy to say that this Sequel is just as much fun entertainment.What i absolutely loved about this Sequel & yes it's definitely a Sequel & not a reboot, is the fact the movie acknowledged the 90's original as it did happen & there's plenty of references to that fact. Some characters mention playing basketball back then & even original Basketball Legend Michael Jordan is mentioned & it just felt right & abit moving to be honest because those Classic events from our childhood fave wasn't forgotten or ignored like some Sequels/Reboots often do.I was also very impressed by Basketball Star, LeBron James here as i found him alot of fun as our star hero & very likeable.I loved the animation both old school cartoon & new CGI of course but all done perfectly. I liked the story (obviously very similar to the original) about how LeBron has to win a basketball game within a wacky universe but this time the universe is within a computer system that controls the worlds & franchises owned by Warner Bros. & that opens up so much fun with tons of characters owned by the famous movie studio, both animated character & movie characters such as Batman, Joker, Pennywise & Mad Max for example. I loved spotting characters in the background.Space Jam: A New Legacy is drenched in amazing animation & Awesome situations & tons of fun. I was actually impressed by everything on screen & was engrossed in this magical fantasy world.Also we get a great new villain here in the form of Silver 'n' shiny suited Don Cheadle (Iron Man 3, Avengers: End Game) & he gives such a fun performance & hey the guy is always great on screen.So yeah i generally really enjoyed this sequel & was totally surprised by that as i thought it would probably suck & i didn't even know who LeBron James was!!!That's the great thing about the Space Jam films is that you don't have to be a basketball fan at all to enjoy these wacky & inventive movies.It was so nice seeing our Toon Squad back together & i got a nice feel of Nostalgia & the new enemy team is actually cool too "Goon Squad" but don't beat the Monstars of course.Space Jam: A New Legacy is simply alot of good fun.

reviews.review_title: WHY IS THIS EVEN A MOVIE...
reviews.content: This movie was hilariously bad. The acting was terrible. And it definitely felt like a Warner Brother's commercial. The jokes were so cheesy and boring. I almost fell asleep four times. 2/10 - Not Recommend!
I had to stop watching. LeBron James should stick to throwing a ball. He should stay away from all forms of media.

reviews.review_title: I feel bad for the kids
reviews.content: Space Jam: A New Legacy (2021)For many years I have been dreaming of a Space Jam sequel and with a heavy heart I admit that this wasn't what I wanted. I am writing these words with a lot of pain in my heart as I am huge fan of Basketball and LeBron James but I can barely find any redeeming qualities for this mess. Space Jam 1 was an easy going film with a simple storyline, plenty of comedy and memorable soundtracks. It was fully aware of it's foolishness and as a result felt highly enjoyable. Space Jam 2 feels like a giant Warner Brothers commerical with too much content making it feel hollow and heartless.It seems like the director was on a mission to saturate every second of this film to the point that it resembles a collection of videos stacked on top each other making it impossible to care for anything. On top of it all, the movie tries to push messages of self actualization but the writer is simply not clever enough to make this or anything else in the film look natural. In a way it feels like a eating a cake stuffed with every imaginable candy while chasing it down with a bucket of chocolate.While I enjoyed watching James and Bugs visit the different WB franchises as they formed that "super" team, eventually the content became excessive. Naturally, Looney Tunes do supply some funny moments and if you are an NBA fan, you will get a few extra laughs. Unfortunately, even basketball itself felt pathetic in this movie. We all remember the Monstars from the original but here, the villains are flat and robotic with the unnecessarily ridiculous Don Cheadle orchestrating the cringefest.However the worst and most noticeable part is the lack of any kind of music. What made Space Jam 1 so special and wholesome were those soundtracks that have kept the film in my heart for years as a pleasant memory. What was supposed to be a goofy comedy about basketball, turned into an excessively long CGI exposition-fest lacking heart , joy or any sort of organic momentum. Space Jam 1 is a cherished memory while Space Jam 2, is a memory that I want to erase from my mind.P. S. I feel sorry for these "kids" who were the target audience.Movies.shmovies on Instagram for movie and TV Shows.

My wife and I sat dish on a Sunday afternoon and popped this movie on We were pleasantly surprised with Space Jam 2. Funny and heartfelt. We had low expectations and came out thinking what a good movie this was.

He's a fraud. Hollywood is too, so I can see why WB thought this would be a good match. Americans are tired of self-entitled, pompous, arrogant blow-hards that appear to hate their audience. Anti-capitalist-capitalists need to give all their money away and move to some country that aligns more with their views. They're not going to do that, obviously, because they are frauds. Lebron is a fraud. Hollywood is a fraud. This movie was awful.

When a person thinks of the looney tunes now, they unknowingly make it a synonymous grouping of all of the tunes. But it wasn't always like that, and anyone that knows the original looney tunes cartoons knows that. A cartoon may contain three, heck, maybe even four looney tunes all together, but never the entire cast! Thus when space jam arrived, collecting all of everyone's favorite loons together in one movie, the praise and excitement was ecstatic. This was the brilliance of space jam, and is one of the reasons why many still love the film. But this left space jam: a new legacy at a disadvantage. People have already seen all the toons together,(twice!) so now what? Well, how about instead of just all the looney tunes getting together, what if ALL Warner brothers properties got together?! Let's be honest, that sounds pretty cool. When you start to think about it a little more though, many problems arise. "How do you account for clashing art styles?" "How do you combine all worlds together while maintaining focus?" And ofcourse "who will replace his airness, Michael Jordan?" The answers: a simple versatile new cartoon style, a complex high tech computer, and the new basketball king, LeBron James. After saying all this, I understand why people feel this isn't space jam. It feels something sort of like space jam, but it's not. It's more like a ready player one spinoff movie than a looney tunes film! And you're right, 100%. I can not argue with you and ignore that and if that's how you feel I 100% understand your resentment towards this film. Personally I found a great deal of enjoyment in this movie, not just from its interesting concept and beautiful(I mean gorgeous) visuals, but from its new lead and story. Unlike many other people, I personally quite liked LeBron in this film, and this may be an unpopular opinion, but I think his acting beats Michaels by a long shot. I understand people thinking he's annoying and a bad father, but to be fair many of his faults are pointed out directly in the film, and he changes for the better by the end of the movie. As for the super computer aspect, I thought it was an interesting, though still kinda dumb idea, and honestly pesters me with more questions of "how???" The more I think about it. The final aspect, it's versatile new cartoon style, is another aspect I expect caused much irritation with the fans. "Why change the art style?" Like I said before, when trying to combine so many art styles, changing some may benefit the overall flow of the film, making it look more... "normal" I suppose. That being said, the looney tunes old design is sorely missed, and I felt that they're redesigns we're honestly unnecessary, and obviously I'm not the only person holding this opinion based on others ratings. And so all the main aspects of the film can either be positives or negatives, based on your expectations from the movie. Personally, I enjoyed it. Are there plot holes? Yes... and the first space jam held none??? In all honesty I wouldn't go into this film with the expectations of seeing a looney tunes film. I'd go into it with the expectation of seeing an epic warner-brothers basketball game, starring the tune squad and LeBron. Simple tweaks in expectations may make it a far more enjoyable experience to some, and I recommend a rewatch with that mindset if you felt unsatisfied with your first viewing.

reviews.review_title: I... did not expect to enjoy this as much as I did.
reviews.content: Based on the trailers that were put out, and then later clips from the movie itself, I figured this would take the appeal and bite of the Looney Tunes, sand down all the edges, and focus instead on making bland advertisement for everything else Warner Bros owns.And it... doesn't? I mean, parts of it do, I guess. The end of the first act is all about traversing the Warner Bros. Universe, interacting with The Matrix and Wonder Woman and all these other WB properties, but it never feels like the point of the movie in the way you get with, say, "Ready Player One" or "Ralph Breaks the Internet."The last comparison is of particular note, because in Disney's movie about a character on a network of branded properties, they chose to have Wreck-it Ralph exploit clickbait for money and make friends with a poor, down-on-his-luck pop-up advertisement. It felt gross, like Disney didn't want to create a conflict of interest with their marketing partners.By comparison, Space Jam: A New Legacy is about Warner Bros inventing a Youtube-esque algorithm to make all of their future movies. It then suggests that, in order to conquer the entertainment industry, they need to sign LeBron James and create a deepfake clone that will star in all Warner movies -- past, present, and future. The real LeBron rightfully says he thinks that idea is stupid, angering the algorithm and giving us our jumping off point for the story.I loved the idea of the algorithm as the movie's villain, and A New Legacy doesn't shy away from making jabs at problems with data privacy and digital rights ownership.This is a movie that has its tongue lodged firmly in cheek. For some, I could see how this could lead them to not connecting with the movie. A New Legacy is big on making fun of something for being bad, while also doing the exact things it's making fun of. I mean, consider what I just said: LeBron James rejects the Warner Bros pitch because he thinks sports stars in movies is dumb, but the whole movie is basically what The Algorithm was trying to make. That kind of double-meta self-aware humor is this whole movie's bread and butter, and either you're in to that, or you aren't.Even the CGI-ification of the Looney Tunes themselves, where they get "upgraded" from traditional cartoon animation to 3D computer graphics is played for meta humor. The Tunes look at themselves, now with realistic fur and skin, and sneer in disgust. It echos the sentiment I saw from some on social media. The movie is drawing attention to its own marketing gimmick and trying to get you to believe that they don't like it either. Whether that's true or not is buried under too many layers of production bureaucracy to know for sure, so I advise you to not think about it too hard. In that light, I thought it was fun, and it at least shows they knew their audience.Which is the whole movie, really. I'm pretty sure I had more fun watching A New Legacy than I would have if I went back and watched the original Space Jam. It's not a perfect movie, and when it does lean in to the pop-culture parade, it's definitely at its worst. But overall, it hit almost every note I could have asked for.

reviews.review_title: Mediocre stuff buoyed by great animation sequences.
reviews.content: SPACE JAM: A NEW LEGACY is pretty much what you'd expect for a film of this kind: it's little more than a commercial for Warner Bros. Property. At the very least it's still superior to the awful RALPH WRECKS THE INTERNET, although that isn't saying much. Still, this film does have its assets. The concept of being trapped in some kind of virtual service world gives the film some vibes of the likes of TRON and even SWORD ART ONLINE. But of course the real highlight are the 2D animated sequences. Bugs Bunny and his co-stars are always a pleasure, and while the animation here lacks some of the 3D shading in places, these scenes are still a delight, particularly in sequences like a chase through DC City and a MATRIX scene. That said the film did lose me a bit in its last hour when the Looney Tunes turn into CG characters (in all fairness, though, at least there is context to it). Going in with low expectations I liked the movie more than I expected to, but it can't be elevated to anything other than mediocre at best. Even so, the audience in the theater seemed to really enjoy it, and you could do a lot worse.

Being a huge fan of the original Space Jam, a sequel wasn't generally a bad idea but I never saw any reason for there to be one. Perhaps one could argue a sequel can work if you got the right talent, the right sports star for it, and a solid plot. It could be possible to do something like this, but you'd need to find all the right things.Space Jam 2 doesn't have any of those elements at all. The film is a complete mess from start to finish. It really has no reason to exist at all. If anything, it makes me wonder why anyone bothered with this in the first place at all. It's painfully obvious though that the film is trying to cash in on nostalgia for those who loved the original Space Jam film. Sure, Space Jam definitely had its weird moments but at least it worked and was fun and entertaining; much more than this film.The first strike against this film is who they chose to be the sports star. So they want to stick with a basketball player, so who do they choose? Somebody fantastic and loved by lots of people? Like maybe Tim Duncan, Dirk Nowitzki, or Kobe Bryant? Nope! Make way for Lebron James. Why he was chosen is beyond me when I felt there were other better choices is beyond. That's only the beginning of the problems with the movie though.If you thought Michael Jordan's wooden acting was bad in the first film, Lebron James is somehow worse. Lebron is either taking things too seriously or is trying too hard to be funny. Jordan's acting was wooden yes, but at least some of the deadpan deliveries got some chuckles from me. Here, James is trying too hard to be serious or funny without balancing it out.The other actors are okay for the most part; given the material they've got to work with. Some of them are good like Bugs and Daffy being pretty good. But the acting in general is really nothing to write home about. It's just passable at its best.Most of the problems with the acting though can be attributed to the awful script. The dialogue is repetitive and it gets tiring really fast. Lebron constantly saying he has to save his son or, more annoyingly, the constant gushing over Lebron James himself. I know the original Space Jam definitely gushed on Michael Jordan, but good lord does this film take it to another level. The movie has to remind us again and again how good Lebron James is, and it gets sickening quickly.Equally bad is the comedy in this movie. The first film's comedy did have some awkward moments in it, but a lot of the jokes worked well and still stand up well to this day. The jokes in this movie are instantly dated or are tiresome. Hearing Granny say "haters gonna hate" just felt cringe worthy and a lot of the visual gags just makes you want to roll your eyes. The only slightly good joke was Sam shooting those basketballs; it got a slight chuckle from me.The CGI and cartoon effects look good for the most part. However, the Looney Tuns don't work out well in the 3D portions. They all look rather poorly designed and facial models (particularly Bugs and Lola) look off and jarring. The other designs are fine for the most part though.The film relies heavily on a lot of winks and nods to other WB properties such as The Iron Giant, some appearances of Harry Potter for some reason, Austin Powers, or A Clockwork Orange. They don't add anything to the movie overall; nor does it serve any purpose aside from some poor fan service. If anything, seeing those characters will remind you there are better films you could be watching than this.The story overall is just an utter bore. The whole movie plays it in a generic way that has very little creative twists or turns. There's very little creativity in this film and the whole movie ends up being by the numbers in how it plays out. There is one twist that may get you off guard, but not by much. There's no sense of fun, no entertainment, and no joy. It just feels boring and dreary.The original Space Jam definitely had its problems for sure, but at least it felt like a fun film that was tongue in cheek entertainment for everyone involved. This movie though feels like it has only one demographic being targeted; very little kids, and I do mean very little. Even then, kids would be more entertained with almost any other movie than this.Do yourself a favor and forget this film happened. Go watch the first Space Jam with Michael Jordan. While that film has its own problems, it can at least still entertain and give some great laughs. This film really serves no point at all other than to be a cheap cash grab. The only legacy this film has is one of wasting your time and being an overall failure.

reviews.review_title: (Mis)using a famous name does not save the day....
reviews.content: I started watching the film fearing that it would be just a mediocre combination of a legend basketball player's life surrounded by many of my favorite cartoon characters à la "Despicable me". Alas, it wasn't even close. The story sucked, the actors, oh well (they're not actors, right? But then why do they act...). No coherence, no character developing, not even enough cartoon moments, no real laughs, nothing to keep you watching. Yes everything is cartoonish, but besides the names and facial features there is nothing reminding me of my childhood's heroes. Also no basketball (I mean real basketball). To my utter disappointment Warner Bros managed to produce a sequel to Space Jam, which is even worse than the first one (and that's no easy task).It is simply one of the worst movies I watched lately, and I am certain, that it wouldn't have made it to the theaters without LeBron's name. It's a pity it finally did....

As movie sequels often go, they are produced due to the well received public and critic reception to the first film, meaning that the second film in a successful film franchise can only go one of two ways; become a box office knock out with a re-imagined perception of the first film along with new and modern visuals and ideas, or risk angering already established fans to the first movie with no originality, or a strong enough chronological link to the first movie in order to connect them together. Space Jam: A New Legacy, does more of the second.The concept of merging NBA legends with animal cartoons is brilliant, original, and has the versatile ability to appeal to all ages, from toddlers to grown adults. What the original Space Jam does seem to lack within its visuals and 3D cinematography aspect, this sequel fails to continue, or even attempt to include.This sequel to the original classic Space Jam somehow loses its humor and playfulness along the way, painfully stringing along overused height and race jokes, having tacky and simply terrible visuals of the cartoon animals, and containing a premise that makes just about as much sense as it's casting does (spoiler: none). However, actress Zendaya, known for her more recent roles as Rue on HBO's "Euphoria" and MJ in Marvel's "Spider Man: Homecoming" succeeds in her role as Lola Bunny, and may be the only saving grace in this entire movie. Whilst this movie receives a 4 overall, LeBron James' acting receives a 1. Barely.Space Jam: A New Legacy really just fails to embody the spirit of the first movie on almost every single line. Fans of the first movie will be extremely disappointed with this sequel, unless they're fans of borderline basic jokes, bad acting, and a confusing plot that nobody will remember.
It was really enjoyable. I say that it was a little bit worse than the original.

reviews.review_title: I Only Gave A Bonus Point for Looney Tunes

reviews.review_title: This ain't the 90s anymore; and that's all folks
reviews.content:
I'm going to be honest here. From a future game developer, an artist and a movie classic appreciator.Space Jam 2 was legitimately a good movie.And before you movie credics from the 90s era that probably reviewed this and are upset by my claim. Let's get it straight, it's not the classic. But the classic was catered to us as kids. This movie, isn't made for us now; it's made for our kids. No of our kids know what it's like to sit at the edge of your seat while Michael Jordan dunks the ball, remembers he was the number1 pick in every basketball game. Still our kids respect Jordan as an athlete, but he isn't what wows the crowds anymore; the game has moved on, and new players are making new history. I really think that's what the debate of space jam is about. We had our space jam in the 90s. We had our looney toons in the 90s, the thing is... It's not the 90s anymore. Times change, and so do people.It's like listening to music. NSYNC, Backstreet boys, Metallica, Korn, Tupac... We listened to that music as kids. We loved it, and would roll our eyes when our parents played something like ready for the world, feeltwood Mac, Johnny cash; because those weren't what was now in our era. As we got older though, we respected our parents choices a
And we may even listen to them now and identify it as good music. Same as our kids nowadays deal with Jordan.The movie from a digital standpoint is great, the cartoons are fun as well; and there are so many things from WBs past that show up in that movie as Easter eggs. The movie takes a videogame digital twist, and the bad guys are pretty cool looking. It's what our newer generations like. And it's a mix with the old and new. Take it how it is, Space Jam 2 is a great movie to enjoy with your family.
Horrible story, bad acting. It's just a disgrace to human nature.
The movie shows no original thought. Quality animation, sure. But the story line and concept just don't work. Cringing the whole time...
It's a generally enjoyable kids movie written by the corporations of NBA and Warner Brothers, just like the original. You get what you expect. It's alright but a little convoluted and long.

reviews.review_title: Bad acting all the way around
reviews.content: We all knew LeBron couldn't really act and he is sort of exempt from actually putting in a good performance. He's LeBron just put him in the movie and surround him with good acting and it would be ok. Nope. Don Cheadle(an extremely good actor) puts in a subpar performance as an antagonist. The voice distortion they give him when he gets upset/angry throughout the movie sounds BAD almost like they went with the first filter they came across in post production and were just like "yep that's good let's move on"The most glaring performance however is from neither the protagonist or antagonist but from the most important character in the movie, Bugs Bunny. Not sure why they didn't just let Billy West do the voice again as he is what Bugs Bunny is supposed to sound like. The guy they got to do it this time sounded off the entire movie and it really sticks out.I watched this movie twice just to make sure what I watched the first time was as bad as I thought it was and it is. I'm sure kids will like it but this does a bad job as a sequel for fans of the original(which would be the parents of those kids)

Great soundtrack and enjoyable family film. I knew starting off this wasn't going to be filled with Oscar worthy moments or acting. That being said go into it open to the possibility of a wholesome family film. This allowed me to really enjoy the film especially compared to the vast majority of the reviews I've read. I will say the last 20 mins was biggest chunk of the film that made it worth watching.

Screw the haters, the only reason why people keep smashing this film to pieces is because "ooh it has way too much product placement". But you know what I think about this movie? It's awesome. I liked spotting the Warner Bros. References, they're one of the reasons why the movie is so fun to watch. I was really looking forward to this movie, and I was hoping that it wouldn't receive negative reviews like the live-action Tom and Jerry movie (which I also liked but not as much as this movie). Unfortunately, it did, and it got a whopping 26% on Rotten Tomatoes, which is ridiculously lower than Tom & Jerry's 31%. I didn't care, and I watched the movie anyway, and I really enjoyed it, and if you think I'm going to watch it on HBO when it gets added to the premium channel in the next few months, you're absolutely right.Overall, I give this a 9/10. This movie will always be more superior than its haters ever will be.

reviews.review_title: Really bad attempt at a sequel
reviews.content: The movie is really bad. It is all about how James thinks he is the GOAT. His acting is horrible and the kids are just as bad. The cartoon characters I loved as a kid have had all their flare removed and seemed flat. James is no Jordan and the fact that they animated him vs. It being his acting shows they knew how bad it would be.

Is there like a prerequisite to overuse CGI nowadays?The original was good because the story was simple, akin to the Looney Toons cartoon series, and the cameos from the other NBA players were simple and light-hearted. The only CGI was the obvious putting the real-world characters into the Looney Toones cartoon setting.In this abomination, for starters the name of the movie doesn't even relate to the theme. It's a cash grab off past glories.There is no mention of outer space in this, WHICH IS HOW THE ORIGINAL GOT ITS NAME. Instead this trash was set inside a computer (game) system. Not even remotely close to outer space.Turning the Looney Toons into 3D stop motion animation was just trying too hard to modernise something that didn't need modernising.LeBron was stiff and too sentimental. The sentiment wasn't needed. Even though MJ was the star attraction of the original, the plot wasn't about him per se. However in this product-placed trash, the movie is all about Lebron and how he's a superior individual who can still be better. Yawn, seen it a thousand times already.The family were just far too perfect too. Except for the son who created the game. He was too self-entitled. Just totally unrelatable, the whole lot of them.The video game was a complete rip-off of NBA Jam too. Didn't try to hide it either.Having the teams scoring in the thousands was just dumb.Fortunately, the kids will be naive to the original and not see how flawed the plot of this abomination combined with LeBron's cardboard acting and they'll probably enjoy the OTT antics of the Looney Toons in this. Me, a childhood fan of Looney Toons and Space Jam, not so much.
